text: so um yeah welcome to our talk here which is going to be called running php apps on.net 5. so before we
get into this just a few quick words about those two languages in particular
so obviously there are two different paradigms there are two different languages frameworks and most likely everyone has
their own preference i suppose and i guess for everyone uh one of those two is going to be a
swear word so the first thing that we just want to get out of the way is that this talk is to be listened to with
an open mind i guess um the project that we're going to talk about in this talk is called peach
pie and it's it's a project that tends to uh bridge the gap between those two technologies and that tries to
bring the two closer together and combine forces in a sense so that's what we're aiming for with this
project and with this talk in general so um just as a quick uh
forward i guess it's important to just keep an open mind and uh try to understand the different use cases um so my name is ben fistein and
i'm here with my colleague jakob mishek together we are part of a company called io level and
we've developed this technology called peachbuy which we're going to talk about in a lot of detail in this talk
so um the first thing that just to lay the ground rules and sort of set the
context for which this this talk is happening if you look at the i guess at least web development
landscape today obviously php is a very very dominant player despite what some people might think of
it in terms of some of its performance or some of its security disadvantages there's quite
clearly a use case for this language it really dominates the the web development landscape
somewhere around 80 percent of all websites are running on some form of php or have some form of php somewhere
and if you look at for example one of the more popular uh applications uh in php called wordpress
they claim at least that about a third of all websites are powered by wordpress so long story short a huge portion of
the internet is powered by this language so clearly there is a use case for it but unfortunately there is also a flip
side because so much of the internet is powered by php there obviously has to be some portion of the
code that's not going to be as good and that's quite clearly the problem the language itself has
undergone a huge development over the last couple of years both in terms of security and development in terms of
performance but still if you look at today's webs roughly 56 percent
of all websites run on some sort of unsupported version of php which might have vulnerabilities or quite
simply has security leaks that were fixed in later versions but um there's quite a bit of difficulty
moving up in versions for php websites sometimes and if it's a business critical application
um you know upping the the version support is sometimes not that easy so over half of all websites still run
on older versions of php also 30 percent of all websites have
some sort of php or vulnerability that can directly be traced back to php
as a comparison for example.net has significantly less it's somewhere probably around 12 to 15
depending on which version you're talking about and then the final point that we're making here
is that if you compare the the performance and you you measured based on memory
consumption php takes up roughly 10 times as much memory as c sharp does and so for all of those
reasons at one point or another we decided wouldn't it be nice or interesting at the very least if we were able to
combine two languages that have kind of opposite advantages and disadvantages and try to
make them into one hybrid application so that was kind of the the thought that powered our uh our thinking behind why
we created peach pie the the general idea is that a lot of
again the internet is built in php but not just websites also um you know internal applications and
these legacy php applications which are difficult to replace or update
have a tendency to cause both business as well as i.t implications if you look at the business side
a lot of them are traced back to that slow performance or some of those security vulnerabilities where
it's really difficult to for first of all refresh your applications if you have a strong dependency on those old
legacy php applications and second of all just by simply having a slower
application and it taking up more memory if you're running your application in the cloud obviously you're going to be
paying uh extra money compared to for example if your application were in asp.net core
which consumes significantly less memory and then finally if you think back a couple years ago
there was a scandal called panama papers in which some very confidential information
leaked from a panamanian law firm and it leaked due to the fact that their website was built in wordpress and was
using a plugin called revolution slider which had a critical vulnerability that they didn't address in their source code
so as a result there are some significant reputational risks that you might incur
from running a php application if it's not properly treated on the i.t
side of course there are also some disadvantages uh first of all php obviously is a an interpreted language
and um in terms of its static analysis and sort of error detection tooling while
you're still coding there's a bit of a limitation there you have some static analysis tools that you can set up externally that you have
to specifically set up and you do have some options of detecting errors but it doesn't work the
same way as a compiled language like c sharp for example would and so we're going to show you some interesting
tricks that arise from that combination of those two languages the second thing is if you look at the
enterprise tooling in the php world there's a lot less of that for the sheer reason that php is an open
source dominated ecosystem so there are some tools and and a lot of them are open source
but in terms of that real enterprise grade software you're going to find it a little bit more difficult to find that
type of software and tooling as compared to net and so this is where we came up with
that idea of peach buy essentially a long time ago peach buzz a compiler and run time of
php on top of net nowadays.net five and it actually really natively
integrates that php language into the dotnet stack in all of its entirety completely natively
because what we did is we essentially rewrote the entire php language all of its functions and
core libraries into c-sharp and ultimately we compile the php code into the same exact
bytecode that for example c-sharp compiles it to we're going to get to why that's important in just a second
the second thing is that we have all of the the uh we essentially replace the the
traditional php runtime and we're able to run all of those php apps on the dotnet runtime
instead but at the same time we maintain compatibility with essentially all php
apps that the project currently supports and then in the real world this is quite a few uh
applications already a pretty wide array of applications that we can completely compatible
that we have complete compatibility with finally or i suppose that the last two
points are a little bit interconnected first of all our architecture is completely run on microsoft roslyn which is a compiler
platform firm from microsoft and essentially what that means is that
first of all we gain a a ton of performance from microsoft's compiler framework just
uh for free and second of all any project that uses roslyn as well is automatically compatible with
peachbuy and as a result through peachbuy you're compatible with all those roslyn based projects as well as a php
application and the final point here is that we can actually
natively integrate php languages into the asp.net core middleware and request pipeline so
essentially what that enables you to do and we're going to show that in a demo in in just a second you can use for example wordpress as a
front-end of your net backend application in a very simple manner
and we're going to show you how that works in just a second so how does peach pie work as a
technology first of all on the input side of course you have php the the traditional php that you're used to all the php
functions that for example wordpress has you just take it and what we produce is two things first
of all we produce roslyn symbols and semantics and a regular dll file which is the same exact
bytecode that for example c sharp produces when you compile c sharp so we produce
this dll and a pdb file and what that gives us is complete bi-directional interoperability
with any dotnet language and anything that uses the net tool chain so obviously it
makes it both way interoperable with c-sharp and f-sharp and visual basic
but also you know net core doesn't exist anymore it's now part of.net five
but not.net core as a as a framework is a completely um multi-platform framework which runs
on just about any anything that has a processor and since it's now part of n5 we we automatically gain that as well
so anything that is on the net standard we're completely compatible with which gives you a ton of interesting use cases
for example you can run your php application on a tizen watch you can run
it on any iot device you can run it with unity so produce for example a mobile app or a
game you can even use a php as a desktop app using winforms so
there are tons of different use cases that um essentially we have for free because we're also running on.net standard
the final point that i want to make here is that because we're essentially targeting this whole
net ecosystem and and framework we are part of the so-called.net foundation which for you means
i guess two things the first one is it'll always be open source to at least to the core technology will
so you can use this technology and it'll remain open source in its in its entirety at least the the
core technology for sure and the second thing if you want to contribute to this project if you have any interesting
uh ideas or actual contribution bug fixes whatever you can simply commit it
and the.net foundation sets up a mechanism where it makes it really easy for you to be a
contributor to it for our project so that's the the main advantage that we get from being in the dotnet foundation
okay so this is all nice i've just explained how peachbuy works and and sort of the
basic background but the main question we always get is why why on earth do we decide to rewrite the
entire php language in c sharp and go through this hassle you know a lot of people think it's
interesting but still they don't really understand why and i suppose there are five main reasons why we decided to do this
back in the day when the project came into existence the main one was performance this was in the days of php3
where php was insanely slow which is no longer the case today but the core reason still today is we
can improve the performance of php applications quite significantly today php has its own jit but at the end
of the day there are still some architectural reasons that net should always be reasonably fast
compared to php and that is for example the fact that php runs on multiple or runs on a
separate thread each time whereas dot net can have multi-threading so
what happens here if you translate it into sort of a business terminology we can still by targeting a few micro uh
situations within an application really boost its performance by hundreds of percent in some cases
and that of course translates to you as a business being able to serve more users concurrently spend
fewer resources on your cloud for example and have a lot of a lot less downtime compared to
regular php another really important reason is security as i've mentioned before a lot of the
internet's vulnerabilities can be traced back to php and the the second reason is quite
simply that php is a dynamic language a lot of uh i guess there's
a lot of bad programming practice involved in in developing sites in php and net quite simply doesn't allow for
some of that to happen so it's a it's a managed type safe language unlike php it's distributed without the source
code and of course you have a lot of different debugging mechanisms that help you during design time to
to catch some errors that php for example doesn't catch so uh you might in in the php
situation you might deploy erroneous code and you'll notice it at a later point in time uh which.net doesn't allow you to do in
general and the second nice reason and we're going to get back to that in the demos
as well is that you can actually distribute your application uh without the source code using the
peach pie mechanism which is an interesting advantage if you want to for example distribute a php
application and perhaps sell it and you don't want to give away the source code but by far the most important reason why
anybody uses peach buy especially in a production setting is interoperability i've mentioned this before and you're
going to see in the live demo how it works but because we compile to the same exact
bytecode that c-sharp compiles to for example we're completely interoperable with any net application and so that gives
you the chance to essentially combine at will between and net within one solution
whatever you prefer in php you can incorporate into your application if you have libraries that you like in php you
simply reference them um you know the compiled nougat packages within your.net application
if you want to override a mechanism of a php site in.net because you think for example it has better security features
you can do that so there's a lot of different advantages in that interoperability feature
and one of the the main ones is that when you're migrating away from for example a php site to.net
using peachbuy you can gradually start replacing parts of your old legacy application with
c-sharp for example and you don't have to make all of the changes at once so you can really take it bit by bit and
gradually improve your website and then there are some some sort of i guess more exotic advantages which is
the the last two as i said before since we run on.net standard you can you can
really have some interesting and exotic use cases a couple that i want to name are for example
using php on iot devices or running php on the client side using
webassembly so on the server side so uh essentially you have uh a couple of interesting
advantages that we haven't explored to to a large extent yet because we're focusing on making the platform as user
friendly as possible but if you really want to play around with this there's really no limitation
anything you can do with net through peach pie you can also do in php
the final one is is sort of i guess a little bit more far-fetched but net is is a completely enterprise-grade
platform and so all the tooling that's available for net especially by microsoft really
caters towards that enterprise setting it's not necessarily that php doesn't have enterprise-grade tooling
but if you want to for example orchestrate your continuous integration and continuous development
pipeline it's significantly more effective with a.net stack
you also get incredible analytics built in right in your visual studio again we're going to show that in a second
so you can actually debug your application to an absolute uh incredible amount of detail and get
all these analytics that are built in and really performance profile your application which is something that
is a little bit more difficult to do in the php world so these are the the main reasons why we
decided to you know maintain this project and why we're still developing it and so in order to show you a little bit
more detail about this we're going to show you a couple of demos so i'm going to pass the word to jacob who's going to show you and walk you through
all those live coding demos that will demonstrate some of these advantages
